instructions.title: Instructions
instructions.content: Begin by clicking one of the categories from the menu. From the dropdown list, click and drag the name to its corresponding location on the map (hints are provided). Correct choices will reveal interesting information. Click the “Close” button to return to the menu. Continue in this manner until you have visited all of the locations.

item.title: Oslo
item.content: Oslo is the capital of Norway and the country’s largest city. It has several historical landmarks, such as the Royal Palace.
item.hint: Hint: This city is located at the edge of a fjord.

item.title: Bergen
item.content: Bergen is the second-largest city in Norway. It has a long history, tracing back to when it was a trading port in the 14th century.
item.hint: Hint: This city is located on the southwestern coast.

item.title: Trondheim
item.content: Trondheim is the fourth-largest city in Norway and is known as an academic hub. It has a long history tracing back to the Viking Age.
item.hint: Hint: This city is situated along a fjord near the Norwegian Sea.

item.title: Bodø
item.content: Bodø was founded in 1816 and is located at the entrance to the Salt Fjord. It is a commercial fishing hub and has several historical landmarks.
item.hint: Hint: This port town is located in northern Norway on the Norwegian Sea.

item.title: Vardø
item.content: Vardø is the oldest town in the northern region and the easternmost corner of Norway. It offers views of the Norwegian–Russian Arctic and the Northeast Passage..
item.hint: Hint: This town is in the far north of Norway.

item.title: Norwegian Sea
item.content: The Norwegian Sea is situated between the Greenland and North Seas. It has a maximum depth of 3,968 m (13,020 ft) and contains deposits of natural gas and oil.
item.hint: Hint: This body of water is northwest of Norway in the Atlantic Ocean.

item.title: North Sea
item.content: This shallow portion of the Atlantic Ocean covers 570,000 sq km (220,000 sq mi). It is one of Europe’s most productive fisheries.
item.hint: Hint: This body of water is south of Norway.

item.title: Greenland Sea
item.content: The Greenland Sea covers an area of 1.2 million sq km (465,000 sq mi). Its average depth is 1,450 m (4,750 ft) and reaches a maximum depth of 4,800 m (16,000 ft).
item.hint: Hint: This body of water is part of the Arctic Ocean.

item.title: Lake Mjøsa
item.content: Lake Mjøsa is approximately 56 km (35 mi) north of Oslo. It is long and narrow, stretching northwest to southeast for 100 km (62 mi).
item.hint: Hint: This lake is located in southeastern Norway.

item.title: Glomma
item.content: The Glomma is the longest river in Scandinavia, running 621 km (386 mi).
item.hint: Hint: This river runs north–south in southern Norway.

item.title: Nord-Norge (Northern Norway)
item.content: Nord-Norge stretches approximately 925 km (575 mi) and is the northernmost point of Europe. It features a mild maritime climate.
item.hint: Hint: This region is the northernmost point of Norway.

item.title: Midt-Norge (Central Norway)
item.content: Midt-Norge, also known as Trøndelag, is the central region of Norway. It covers an area of 41,383 sq km (15,978 sq mi) and surrounds the Trondheims Fjord.
item.hint: Hint: This region is below Nord-Norge.

item.title: Vestlandet (Western Norway)
item.content: Vestlandet is in southwestern Norway, stretching over an area of approximately 58,512 sq km (22,592 sq mi).
item.hint: Hint: This region borders the North Sea.

item.title: Sørlandet (Southern Norway)
item.content: Sørlandet is a strip of lowland along the southernmost region of Norway. It covers an area of 16,435 sq km (6,346 sq mi).
item.hint: Hint: This region forms the southern coast of Norway.

item.title: Østlandet (Eastern Norway)
item.content: Østlandet stretches from Norway’s Jotunheim Mountains to the coastal lowlands near Oslo Fjord. It encompasses 94,576 sq km (36,516 sq mi).
item.hint: Hint: This region is in the southeastern region of the country.

item.title: Galdhopiggen
item.content: Galdhø Peak in English, this summit rises to 2,469 m (8,100 ft), making it the highest point on the Scandinavian Peninsula.
item.hint: Hint: This point is located in the center of southern Norway.

item.title: Svalbard
item.content: Svalbard consists of nine major islands. It encompasses an area of 62,701 sq km (24,209 sq mi)
item.hint: Hint: This archipelago lies along the Greenland Sea.

item.title: Lofoten Islands
item.content: The Lofoten Islands is an archipelago that encompasses 1,227 sq km (474 sq mi). It is known for its numerous fishing villages.
item.hint: Hint: These islands are part of Nord-Norge.
